sections.paragraphs:
In [[mathematics]], the term "'''almost all'''" means "all but a negligible amount". More precisely, if <var>X</var> is a [[set (mathematics)|set]], "almost all elements of <var>X</var>" means "all elements of <var>X</var> but those in a [[negligible set|negligible]] [[subset]] of <var>X</var>". The meaning of "negligible" depends on the mathematical context; for instance, it can mean [[finite set|finite]], [[countable set|countable]], or [[null set|null]].{{r|group=sec|Glossary}}

In contrast, "'''almost no'''" means "a negligible amount"; that is, "almost no elements of <var>X</var>" means "a negligible amount of elements of <var>X</var>".

sections.title: Meanings in different areas of mathematics

values.value: According to the [[prime number theorem]], the number of primes less than or equal to <var>n</var> is asymptotically equal to <var>n</var>/ln(<var>n</var>). Therefore, the proportion of primes is roughly ln(<var>n</var>)/<var>n</var>, which tends to 0 as <var>n</var> tends to [[infinity]], so the proportion of composite numbers less than or equal to <var>n</var> tends to 1 as <var>n</var> tends to [[infinity]].{{r|Hardy2}}

sections.title: Prevalent meaning
Meaning in measure theory
Meaning in number theory

values.value: According to the [[prime number theorem]], the number of primes less than or equal to <var>n</var> is asymptotically equal to <var>n</var>/ln(<var>n</var>). Therefore, the proportion of primes is roughly ln(<var>n</var>)/<var>n</var>, which tends to 0 as <var>n</var> tends to [[infinity]], so the proportion of composite numbers less than or equal to <var>n</var> tends to 1 as <var>n</var> tends to [[infinity]].{{r|Hardy2}}

sections.title: Meaning in graph theory
Meaning in topology
Meaning in algebra
sections.paragraphs: In [[abstract algebra]] and [[mathematical logic]], if <var>U</var> is an [[ultrafilter#Special case: ultrafilter on the powerset of a set|ultrafilter]] on a set <var>X</var>, "almost all elements of <var>X</var>" sometimes means "the elements of some ''element'' of <var>U</var>".{{r|Komjath|Salzmann|Schoutens|Rautenberg}} For any [[partition of a set|partition]] of <var>X</var> into two [[disjoint sets|disjoint]] sets, one of them will necessarily contain almost all elements of <var>X</var>. It is possible to think of the elements of a [[filter (mathematics)#Filter on a set|filter]] on <var>X</var> as containing almost all elements of <var>X</var>, even if it isn't an ultrafilter.{{r|Rautenberg}}
